variant.question:
In general, directional controllability with one engine inoperative on a multi-engine aeroplane is favourably affected by:
 
1) high temperature
 
2) low temperature
 
3) aft CG location
 
4) forward CG location
 
5) high altitude
6) low altitude
 The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is

An aeroplane, being manually flown in the speed unstable region, experiences a disturbance that causes a speed reduction. If the altitude is maintained and thrust remains constant, the aeroplane speed will:

options.text: initially further decrease and thereafter increase.

variant.question: After the engine start, the pilots forget to set the flaps for departure and the aircraft is in clean configuration. What is most likely to happen?

options.text: A normal takeoff will occur with no noticeable differences
The aircraft will be unable to provide enough tail force and will not lift off the runway.
The takeoff is safe if the performance is done and VR is calculated

variant.question: Which plane and situation experiences the least amount of lift reduction?
An aircraft has speed instability when:
What is the effect on Minimum Control Speeds as density altitude increases?

options.text: Because thrust is decreased, Minimum Control Speeds decrease.
Because thrust is increased, Minimum Control Speeds increase.
Because thrust is decreased, Minimum Control Speeds increase
Because thrust is increased, Minimum Control Speeds decrease

variant.question:
Which of the following conditions have an adverse effect on control in asymmetric flight?
1.  Low altitude
2.  High air density
3. High temperature
4. Low temperature
An aeroplane is at risk of a low speed stall under the following circumstances:

options.text: Descending at a constant Mach number.

variant.question: Under which of these circumstances is an aeroplane at risk of a low speed stall?

options.text: Descending at a constant Mach number.

variant.question: A pilot is on approach to an airport when the pilot receives a warning. While the problem is being solved, the controls feel light and unresponsive. This is due to...

A pilot is on approach and is momentarily distracted by an alternator failure. On turning final, the controls feel light, the control surfaces are unresponsive and the pilot struggles to maintain bank angle. This is due to:
A fly-by-wire aircraft gives you protections to remain stabilized regarding mass & balance and centre of gravity data. What may happen on takeoff if you enter the wrong centre of gravity?

options.text: The aircraft might become unstable in certain configurations.
The aircraft will never become unstable due to regulations preventing this.
Fuel consumption will increase because the aircraft moves the stabilizer to correct for the incorrect CG position.
Drag increases because the aircraft will try to trim for the actual CG.

variant.question: For this question refer to the image.  The image shows two aeroplanes, aeroplane 1 and aeroplane 2.  Both aeroplanes have the same fly-by-wire system capable of maintaining the aeroplane's trajectory at all times, unless being modified by the pilot or autopilot.  Due to a sensor failure in each aeroplane, the fly-by-wire systems downgrade and the aeroplanes revert to a conventional style back-up control with a direct relationship between the control column position and the control surface position.  What are the implications to the pilots?

options.text: Both aeroplanes 1 and 2 will have significantly different behaviour and control feel due to the absence of a computer compensating for the effects of changing configuration or thrust.
Both aeroplanes 1 and 2 will have similar behaviour since they are statically stable and in both cases the aeroplane will return to its trimmed position after configuration or thrust changes.
Aeroplane 1 will behave and feel very similar to normal, while aeroplane 2 will have significant changes in pitch control and feel, with a risk of entering pilot-induced oscillations.
Aeroplane 1 will feel significantly different in pitch with large trim changes as a result of thrust changes, while aeroplane 2 may suffer control reversal and loss of control feel.

variant.question: In general, control forces are reduced by:

options.text: a horn balance, servo tab and spring tab.
a balance tab, forward shift of the CG and a servo tab.
mass balancing, a trim tab and spring tab.
a servo tab, spring tab and mass balancing.

variant.question: What are the primary roll controls on a conventional aeroplane?
An aircraft is flown at 20% below its normal mass. Because of this, V~A~ will be:

Refer to an emergency landing with an instructor in a multi-engine piston airplane with one engine inoperative. The maximum take-off mass is 6 000 kg.  Which of the following conditions is most favourable for such emergency landing?

options.text: 2 800 kg for less yawing moment due to asymmetric thrust.
5 800 kg for less yawing moment due to asymmetric thrust.

variant.question:
A Flight Instructor is about to start a training flight with a student pilot on a multi-engine aeroplane, the lesson is on aeroplane control during engine failures. The training syllabus for this lesson includes practising engine failures during the cruise phase of flight.
Which of the following possible conditions would be beneficial for this training flight and assist the student pilot with aircraft controllability? 
Aircraft MTOW 6000 kg. An aeroplane mass of.....?

options.text: 5600 kg, for less yawing moment due to asymmetric thrust.
2800 kg, for less yawing moment due to asymmetric thrust.

variant.question:
A Flight Instructor is about to start a training flight with a student pilot on a multi-engine aeroplane, the lesson is on aeroplane control during engine failures. The training syllabus for this lesson includes practising engine failures during the cruise phase of flight.Which of the following possible conditions would be beneficial for this training flight and assist the student pilot with aircraft controllability?
Aircraft MTOW 6000 kg. An aeroplane mass of..

options.text: 2800 kg, for less yawing moment due to asymmetric thrust.
5600 kg, for less yawing moment due to asymmetric thrust.

variant.question: A flight instructor is teaching a student of a multi-engine piston airplane the practice of an engine failure during cruise flight. Which of the following masses would be beneficial and assist the student in controlling the airplane during the first engine failure exercise, and why? (Note: The maximum take-off mass is 6 000 kg)

options.text: 2 800 kg, for less yawing moment due to asymmetric thrust.
5 600 kg, for less yawing moment due to asymmetric thrust.

variant.question: A twin-engine propeller aircraft suffers an engine failure. Under which of these circumstances is retention of control likely to be most difficult?

options.text: Aerodrome at low density altitude, critical engine failure at the point of go-around.
Aerodrome at high density altitude, critical engine failure after take-off.
Aerodrome at low density altitude, critical engine failure after take-off.
Aerodrome at high density altitude, critical engine failure at the point of go-around.

variant.question:
V~MCA~ is the minimum speed at which directional control can be maintained when, amongst others:

1. maximum take-off thrust was set and is maintained on the remaining engines.2. a sudden engine failure occurs on the most critical engine.3. flaps are in any position.4. the gear is either up or down.5. the aeroplane is either in or out of ground effect.
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is:
Which situation has the most adverse effect on controllability with one engine out?
For a propeller engine aircraft, regarding the minimum control speed, which of the following statements is true?

options.text:
For a normally aspirated engine, an increase in altitude
decreases the minimum control speed.

For a normally aspirated engine, an increase in altitude
does not change the minimum control speed.

For a normally aspirated engine, an increase in altitude
increases the minimum control speed.

For a turbocharged engine, an increase in altitude
decreases the minimum control speed.

variant.question: Consider a light twin-engine piston airplane performing ago-around at an airfield with a temperature of ISA -10 °C. What will be the influence on V~MCA ~in case of an engine failure?

options.text: A high engine performance on the operating engine, due to the higher air density, will cause the VMCA to increase.
The high air density will increase the effectiveness of the controls so VMCA will decrease.
A high engine performance on the operating engine, due to the higher air density, will cause the VMCA to decrease.
The low air temperature will decrease the effectiveness of the controls so VMCA will increase.

variant.question: The calibrated airspeed during the take-off run at which, when the critical engine is suddenly made inoperative, it is possible to maintain control of the aeroplane using the rudder control alone, and the lateral control to the extent of keeping the wings level to enable the take-off to be safely continued using normal piloting skill, is called..

The calibrated airspeed during the take-off run at which, when the critical engine is suddenly made inoperative, it is possible to maintain control of the aeroplane using the rudder control alone, and the lateral control to the extent of keeping the wings level to enable the take-off to be safely continued using normal piloting skill, is called..

The calibrated airspeed during approach and landing, with all engines operating, at which, when the critical engine is suddenly made inoperative, it is possible to maintain control of the aeroplane with that engine still inoperative, and maintain straight flight with an angle of bank of not more than 5°, is called...

The calibrated airspeed during approach and landing, with all engines operating, at which, when the critical engine is suddenly made inoperative, it is possible to maintain control of the aeroplane with that engine still inoperative, and maintain straight flight with an angle of bank of not more than 5°, is called

The calibrated airspeed during approach and landing, with all engines operating, at which, when the critical engine is suddenly made inoperative, it is possible to maintain control of the aeroplane with that engine still inoperative, and maintain straight flight with an angle of bank of not more than 5°, is called..
Maintaining directional control with one engine inoperative using the banking method, compared to the wings-level method, can result in directional control problems at..

options.text: light aeroplane masses, due to the reduced lateral component of weight.
heavy aeroplane masses, due to the increased lift and drag.
light aeroplane masses, due to the reduced lateral component of drag.
heavy aeroplane masses, due to the increased stall speed.

variant.question: Maintaining directional control with one engine inoperative using the banking method, compared to the wings-level method, can result in directional control problems at...

options.text: low mass, due to the smaller component of weight acting parallel to the rudder force.
heavy aeroplane masses, due to the increased stall speed.
light aeroplane masses, due to the reduced lateral component of drag.
heavy aeroplane masses, due to the increased lift and drag.

variant.question: Maintaining directional control with one engine inoperative using the banking method, compared to the wings-level method, can result in directional control problems at

options.text: light aeroplane masses, due to the reduced lateral component of weight.
heavy aeroplane masses, due to the increased stall speed.
heavy aeroplane masses, due to the increased lift and drag.
light aeroplane masses, due to the reduced lateral component of drag.

variant.question: While going around in an airport with temperature at negative 10 degrees, a light twin-engine aircraft with normally-aspirated piston engines experiences an engine failure. How will the environment described affect V~MCA~?

options.text: High engine performance on the operating engine due to high air density will increase V~MCA~.
Increased effectiveness of controls due to high air density will decrease V~MCA~.
High engine performance on the operating engine due to high air density will decrease V~MCA~.
Decreased effectiveness of controls due to low air temperature will increase V~MCA~.

variant.question: An aircraft is taking off from a sea-level aerodrome with an outside air temperature below 15 degrees. What should a pilot be aware of regarding the controllability with one-engine inoperative?

options.text: A high V~MC~ due to the engine's high performance.
A high V~MC~ due to excessive rudder efficiency.
A low V~MC~ due to excessive rudder efficiency.
A low V~MC~ due to the engine’s high performance.

variant.question:
The following conditions have an adverse effect on control in asymmetric flight:1. Low altitude 
 2. High air density 
 3. High temperature 
 4. Low temperature
Given a multi engine aeroplane, which of the following combinations will give the least control problem during an engine failure?

options.text: An aircraft with the left propeller turning clockwise and the right propeller turning anticlockwise.
An aircraft with both propellers turning clockwise.
An aircraft with both propellers turning anticlockwise.
An aircraft with the left propeller turning anticlockwise and the right propeller turning clockwise.

variant.question: With regards to asymmetric controllability, which of the following conditions would allow control to be maintained down to the lowest speed?

options.text: CG position on the forwards limit.

CG position slightly aft of the aft limit (assuming some
other factor did not cause a loss of control).
CG position on the aft limit.
CG position in the middle of the envelope.

variant.question:
V~MCL~ can be limited by:
1) engine failure on take-off.
2) roll rate.

In the case of engine failure you will get your lowest
control speed in flight with:
Consider a multi-engine aeroplane. In order to achieve the best possible climb performance, which of the following methods is used to maintain control after an engine failure?

options.text: Rudder to stop yaw, aileron to bank towards the live engine.
Rudder to stop yaw, aileron to bank towards the failed engine.
Aileron to stop yaw, rudder to keep the slip indicator centred.
Rudder to stop yaw, aileron to maintain wings level.
